clinical_study.brief_title: Antiretroviral Treatment Outcomes in HIV-HBV Co-infected Patients in Southern Africa
clinical_study.official_title: CIDRZ-1220 Antiretroviral Treatment Outcomes in HIV-HBV Co-infected Patients in Southern Africa: a Collaborative Multi-country Prospective Cohort Analysis for International Epidemiologic Databases to Evaluate AIDS- Southern Africa (HIV/HBV-coinfection in IeDEA-SA)
clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to establish a cohort of patients starting antiretroviral therapy (ART) with chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection and study the effect of chronic HBV on HIV- and liver-related outcomes according to ART regimen and site.

detailed_description.textblock: The study will take place during routinely scheduled ART visits as per Ministry of Health. Routinely collected programmatic data will be used to assess general HIV outcomes (CD4 response, loss to follow-up, death) as well as collecting study specific data (hepatitis testing, questionnaire regarding risk factors for hepatitis/liver disease, and non-invasive liver scan) to address other aims. The study will be implemented at three sites with a total enrollment across all sites of 3000 participants. However our site will only enroll 1000.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.description: a linear mixed effect model will be used to evaluate immunological response

secondary_outcome.description: Virological response will be evaluated using Cox regression analyses.
These events will be defined as an increase in the level of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) or aspartate aminotransferase (AST) > 5 time the upper limit within the first year of ART.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: baseline and one year after start of ART
secondary_outcome.description: the prevalence of liver fibrosis will be measured to compare HIV/hepatitis coinfected versus HIV monoinfected patients using transient elastography.
The presence of HBV drug resistance in co-infected patients who fail treatment after 1 year will be measured
The incidence of HBV infection during the first year of ART will be measured.

secondary_outcome.measure: Predictors of hepatitis coinfection and liver fibrosis
secondary_outcome.description: Predictors such as heavy alcohol use, drug use, and sexual behaviors will be measured.

arm_group.description: 800 to 920 our site (1100 to 1230 in total) patients without chronic HBV infection
50 to 80 participants at our site (100 to 170 patients across all sites) with chronic HBV infection

intervention.description: routine standard of care per Ministry of Health protocol including blood draws and examinations.

biospec_descr.textblock: The laboratory will store any leftover blood specimens for up to 5 years for hepatitis related serologic, immunological, and virologic studies pending availability of funding. Use of specimens for any tests outside the realm of the goals and objectives of this study will require additional approval by the REC.

study_pop.textblock: Enrollment of 1,000 consecutive patients starting ART at each of the three sites is planned.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- HIV-infected
- Male or female aged ≥18 years
- ART naïve
- ART eligible as defined by Zambian or WHO treatment guidelines
- Initiating an ART regimen including at least 3 drugs at one of the study sites.
- Willing to provide signed informed consent and be followed at the clinical site.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are not planning to remain in the catchment area from which they were recruited for the duration of the study
